resources.string: This is a placeholder string for popups.

Welcome to InstaGraph!

 This app features data visualisation and time series forecasting capabilities, broken into five steps:

 1. Get Data: Provide a URL to a file containing your data in a CSV format.

 2. Select Graph: Choose between a selection of charts to visualise your data.

 3. Select Columns: Pick which columns will be plotted, as well as what forecasting model will be used to make predictions. The chosen model can be customised to experiment with different parameters.

 4. Predict: The selected visualisation is created using the specified columns.

 5. Result: Using the model of your choice, future values are predicted and graphed along with the original data.
Tap to display information about InstaGraph.

An unknown error occurred when trying to plot the predictions. Please try again or use a different URL.
No SES parameters are available to customise. The smoothing parameter α is optimised by default.
Limit the number of rows used\n(Leave blank to use all rows).
Your custom parameters could not be retrieved. Please try again.
An unknown error occurred when retrieving custom parameters. Please try again.
URL cannot be blank. Please enter a value for URL and try again.
There are not enough rows in the dataset to predict values. Please adjust the row limit or use a bigger dataset and try again.
Not enough rows of been selected. Please use at least 2 rows.
Enter the number of predictions to make\n(Leave blank to predict 12 steps ahead.

Autoregression: Uses a selection of past values to predict future ones using regression.

 Order: The number of past values to consider.

 Trend: Inform the model that there is a trend (general upward or downward drift of values) in your data.

Autoregressive Integrated Moving Average: A combination of the autoregression*, differencing** and moving average***.

 AR Order: The number of past values to consider.

 Diff Order: The order of differencing to apply (usually 1 or 2).

 MA Order: The number of previous prediction errors to consider.

 Trend: Inform the model that there is a trend (general upward or downward drift of values) in your data. *Autoregression: Uses a selection of past values to predict future ones using regression.

 **Differencing: The process of taking the difference between observations to make the data independent of time. The order of differencing refers to how many times the difference between observations is taken.

 ***Moving Average: Uses the error of previous predictions to improve future ones in a regression-like fashion.

Simple Exponential Smoothing: Useful when a trend or seasonal pattern is not clear. SES associates a weight to all observations, which is a measure of its relevance when predicting future values. Larger weights are applied to more recent observations and the weights decrease exponentially over time. The decay of the weights is controlled by the smoothing parameter α.

Holt-Winter’s Exponential Smoothing: One variation of exponential smoothing that assigns a weight to all observations. Larger weights are applied to recent values, and the weight decays exponentially over time. HWES accounts for any trend or seasonality in your data.

 Trend: The type of trend. Additive means there is some constant variation throughout the data. Multiplicative indicates the change is proportional to the level of the series (the average value of data at a particular time).

 Seasonal: The type of seasonality. Additive means there is some constant variation throughout the data. Multiplicative indicates the change is proportional to the level of the series (the average value of data at a particular time).

 Seasonal Period: The number of observations within a season. For example, a period of 12 in monthly data implies a yearly seasonal pattern, 7 for weekly, 4 for quarterly, etc.
Note: All parameters are optional. Fields left blank will assume a default value.
The columns cannot be the same. Please try again.
The seasonal period must be greater than 2.
Please note: This app is best suited to small datasets (less than 1000 rows). Larger datasets will take significant time to process and there is a limit of 3000 rows.
There are too many rows in this dataset. Please choose a dataset with less than 3000 rows.
